Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: Center for Electrochemical Processes and Technology (CEProTECH)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The I/UCRC for Electrochemical Processes and Technology plans to advance the fundamentals of electrochemical science and engineering to enhance production and manufacturing applications. CEProTECH will combine four research thrusts: (1) multiscale-modeling (from materials to electrochemical systems), economics and life cycle analysis, (2) in-situ electrochemical spectroscopy and microscopy techniques, (3) prototyping and scale-up, and (4) rapid transfer of technology to industry (technology roadmap based on industry member needs).

The proposed I/UCRC will seek to sustain a holistic portfolio of novel, advanced and industrially applicable research. This research agenda will be executed by a multi-disciplinary team, including a significant percent of underrepresented groups of faculty, research scientists, and numerous undergraduate and graduate students, as well as post-docs. Student researchers at the Center will receive important experience that will help contribute to the creation of an educated and contextually trained new-generation workforce. The Center plans to encourage a broad dissemination of learning through its continuing education activities to assist engineers in industry, as well as engineering students, in acquiring knowledge of electrochemical processes to better prepare them for career advancements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of the work was on development of efficient computational tools for electrochemical processes and application to battery management systems and electro-organic synthesis.

In the battery management systems and adaptive predictive control of energy  storage systems, the modeling of solid state diffusion and intercalation of Li into the electrode was a computationally difficult step and hence only simpler empirical models was used in earlier studies. In this work we have developed more efficient reduced order models using mathematically efficient spectral collocation methods The solid phase diffusion coefficient was also assumed to vary as a function of state of charge which is another novel contribution of the work. The results showed dramatic savings in computational time compared to finite difference models. Hence the models can now be incorporated into more detailed analysis of battery management systems and the simpler models used in earlier studies can be improved leading to improved performance of the energy storage systems. The work will be useful in automobile and solar energy storage industries..

 

In the work on modeling of electro-organic processes, detailed analysis of diffusional effects near the film or the boundary layer near the electrode is not studied in detail due to the stiff nature of the differential equations due to fast reactions. The reaction, for example in adioponitrile synthesis, involves multiple heterogeneous and homogeneously  reactions. The product selectivity is also affected by diffusional effects. Efficient methods using boundary integral methods was used to model these set of reactions and MATLAB codes were developed which can be used as  general purpose computational tool for design of these reactors. This will lead to a more detailed incorporation of detailed chemistry and diffusional effects into modeling of electrochemical reactors thereby improving the performance of these reactors.  The work will be useful for chemical and pharmaceutical industries.


Last Modified: 05/31/2016
Modified by: P. A Ramachandran
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The focus of the work was on development of efficient computational tools for electrochemical processes and application to battery management systems and electro-organic synthesis. In the battery management systems and adaptive predictive control of energy storage systems, the modeling of solid state diffusion and intercalation of Li into the electrode was a computationally difficult step and hence only simpler empirical models was used in earlier studies. In this work we have developed more efficient reduced order models using mathematically efficient spectral collocation methods The solid phase diffusion coefficient was also assumed to vary as a function of state of charge which is another novel contribution of the work. The results showed dramatic savings in computational time compared to finite difference models. Hence the models can now be incorporated into more detailed analysis of battery management systems and the simpler models used in earlier studies can be improved leading to improved performance of the energy storage systems. The work will be useful in automobile and solar energy storage industries.. In the work on modeling of electro-organic processes, detailed analysis of diffusional effects near the film or the boundary layer near the electrode is not studied in detail due to the stiff nature of the differential equations due to fast reactions. The reaction, for example in adioponitrile synthesis, involves multiple heterogeneous and homogeneously reactions. The product selectivity is also affected by diffusional effects. Efficient methods using boundary integral methods was used to model these set of reactions and MATLAB codes were developed which can be used as general purpose computational tool for design of these reactors. This will lead to a more detailed incorporation of detailed chemistry and diffusional effects into modeling of electrochemical reactors thereby improving the performance of these reactors. The work will be useful for chemical and pharmaceutical industries. Last Modified: 05/31/2016 Submitted by: P. A Ramachandran
